reviewText:
“There are wounds that never show on the body that are deeper and more hurtful than anything that bleeds.”
― Laurell K. Hamilton, Mistral's Kiss

In less than twenty minutes, The Static Speaks My Name, delivers a gut-wrenching tale that delves directly into the sensitive subject matter of depression in a beautiful, yet twisted way.

Depicting the story of a thirty-one year old man by the name of, Jacob Emholtz, The Static Speaks My Name showcases the warped perspective of an obsessive man who, in his quest to solve the the non intelligible meaning that lies within a painting of two trees, loses sight of his own morality, slipping slowly and slowly into an introverted state.

What our protagonist fails to realize, however, is that his dissection of the painting is not spawned on the basis of curiosity, as much as a self-reflection pertaining to his constant descent into an unrelenting spire of depression.  In search for justification to his sorrows, Jacob distorts his true objective of discovering self-worth, into a direct, but unavailing task that consumes him entirely.

Once gripped with depression, introspection only leads to greater despair.

The game-play and graphical style is very, very simplistic, but the game still manages to be very atmospheric.  I do wish a bit more... emphasis was put on the paintings (many players will simply miss the whole basis behind the game as it fails to push the player even slightly in the correct direction).  This was a major flaw in the development of the story that may push away players.  That said, I very much enjoyed the game.


Though I am not fully satisfied with the above phrasing and grammar as I feared to spoil the game entirely (and night-shift is an absolute killer, haha), I simply must implore those who have not yet played this game to invest the ten minutes of your time.  It is most certainly worth it.  The message may not cut as deeply to some than others, but the story is unique enough that I believe most will most certainly enjoy the tale.

As a side-note, though the developer provides a “trigger-warning” for those stricken with emotional grief, I would still absolutely recommend this game.  Though sorrow has gripped me plenty times throughout the years, I personally have found that contemplating/observing unique perspectives on somewhat... taboo subjects allows for me to reconcile with the issues that cloud my mind.

The Static Speaks My Name is a short title, but it conveys a powerful message.


Edit: It would be phenomenal if a more, full experience (multiple stories) could be added.  If a game was developed with multiple stories, I would most certainly purchase it at a reasonable price.


Edit Two: The keys on the wall next to the televisions are there for a reason.  Search around a bit and you might find some interesting things.  The game rewards exploration, even when in such a small space.

reviewText:
I don't think the people giving this game negative reviews really 'get' it. This review does contain spoilers so read at your own risk. Actual review at the bottom.

The whole point of walking through the 'menial tasks' is to show you what it's like to be severely depressed. This guy has someone locked up in a cage (who he kills) and then plans to hang himself. And yet he walks around doing these inane tasks like cleaning the microwave, talking to cam girls and...eating live shrimp like it aint no thang. The whole point is the feeling of detachment this guy has from life. He's going to kill himself and yet he still finds the time to clean the ♥♥♥♥ing microwave! Anyone who has been depressed at some point in their life, no matter how deeply, can relate to that feeling of apathy. As for the painting - what's wrong with coming to your own conclusions? Surely there's an element of fun in trying to figure out what the hell this guy has been doing with his life obsessing over a painting? Some stories don't need an explanation, it's more enjoyable leaving us lot to argue about the backstory!

This is a weird but enjoyable (sort of) little story/game that does a good job of conveying the feeling of detachment that depressed people often feel. You can sense it just by playing it. It's only 10 minutes long, if that, so for the grand total of zero pounds and zero pence, you might as well give it a go.

'The Static Speaks my Name' is a great and rather unusual quick 10 minute game. There honestly is little to nothing to say about this game, as it is very short, and I'll have to add a spoiler alert to add content to this review. I'd recommend this game, it only takes about 10 minutes to play. However, be warned, this game does contain some rather dark and depressing topics.

The story is of a man so obsessed with a painting, a palm tree on a small desert island, most likely in the middle of an ocean. You play as the man's last night alive. The game itself is very short, and quite unusual, with simplistic tasks such as 'Using the bathroom' and 'Cleaning the microwave', then 'Deciding what to do with the man in the cage'.

I'll have to add a spoiler alert to these next parargraphs, as I'll tell the story, as some players didn't seem to understand it. You play as a rather odd man who's obsessed with a painting. Your tasks at the beginning require you to use the bathroom and get breakfast. However, there is nothing to eat, so the man resorts to eating 2 of his pet shrimps. The only room that you are not required to use is filled with the same painting all over the walls. Your character seems to have studied and cracked down on everything this simplistic palm tree painting has to offer; it'd also seem likely that your character has made some crazy conspiricies and observations.

One of your last taks is to decide what to do with the man in your cage. Before this, you have no understanding of this man in a cage. You're forced to pick up your keys (hung up next to your coat on a rack) and use them to open a bookcase that reveals a safe, in which a man, most likely the artist of your obsessed painting, is locked in a cage. You unlock the cage and then 'put yourself to rest', in which you open a door in your room which previously would've said 'not yet..' when you tried to interact with it. In this room is a noose, you commit suicide and wake up in a dark space filled with static clouds, all of which show names, ages and way of suicide when you get close to them. The game ends.

I wanted to give this game a negative review at first, but then I saw that the little amount of gameplay was more or less intentional, so since this is the way it's supposed to be, it gets a pass.

A mysterious, unsettling yet interesting 15 minutes...
It's no joke; the game really is that short - even after checking out everything there is to see.
I don't want to go too much into detail here since the game is already very short on its own, so I'll just point out some things I thought were especially good.

The second objective is what really set the mood (in case the music hasn't kicked in fully yet, or if the TVs in the hallway weren't already strange enough), and added to the general theme of the game (the main character being insane/mentally ill).

Without a doubt the most interesting thing in this game would be the painting room.
A room full of copies of the same painting - some of them in different versions (to (probably) point out the protagonists mental illness - obsession).

Then we have the only real puzzle in the game.
Somewhere, a document points out how to put books into a shelf to make it seem casual" - this is a hint for a puzzle in order to find the vault containing the man in the cage.

The music was really effective in making this a somewhat creepy experience.
It made me feel rushed or followed in a way

Very short

reviewText:
Warning, this review contains major spoilers!

This isn't a game so much as an exercise in immersing the player in the life of someone else for a few minutes.  And what a life it is.  At first things seem normal enough.  You wake up in your one bedroom dwelling in which you spend the entire, very short, game . Simple objectives given on the screen.  Go to the bathrooom.  Eat breakfast.  Normal stuff.  And then... some not so normal stuff.

The enviroment that seems so normal when you first start playing contains hints of how very sad and lonely this life you find yourself in really is.   The empty fridge, the state of the doors and windows,  the fact that apparently you consider a chat sex bot to be one of your best friends, the note you've written to your mom... It becomes clear that you are inhabiting someone whose life has gone very, very wrong.  And then... things get much worse.

There are no jump scares in this game.  No monsters hunt you.  No gunfire, magic spells, or ghosts.  And yet, it manages to be genuinely creepy and disturbing.  Give this one a pass if a graphic portrayal of depression, mental illness, murder, and suicide might be a trigger for your own burdens.  For everyone else,  I think it's worth checking how successful a very non-standard game can be so successful at what it clearly sets out to do.

No number rating because how the heck do you even start to quantify something like that in a game like this?

reviewText:
It's easily arguable about how 'brilliant' this game is, and people do. Some shame you if you don't get the point of it, or appreciate what makes it 'genius'. The others berate you for being so interested in what makes this game what it is.

I find it hard to give it any pros or cons, because in the end, it really depends on who you are. This game is about obsessive behavior, and what caused it and stemmed from it. It's a short game, and even when you stop to inspect it piece by piece, it won't take you very long. If you're like me, and feel relatable to behaviors of the character, you'll do your best to linger and try to derive insight from it to use for yourself.

If you have the time to sit and ponder for two or less hours, you'll probably enjoy this game. That's really the only way to play it--it's all about trying to figure out what exactly it's all about.

reviewText:
Here shrimpyyyyy...

This is indeed an interesting little concept.

Story Breakdown You play as a man on the last day of his life. He wakes, pees, obsesses over this one strange painting, feeds himself with his buddies, talks to his friend on the internet, decides what to do with a... The cage, and then puts his body to rest.

My first forewarning is to not go into this expecting a game. As even said in the description of the game, it's a 10 minute dark, moody and rather depressing atmospheric story. Nothing more, nothing less. Once you figure out what the ending line means, you feel the weight of this.

Graphics Decent enough, obviously not the prettiest and most polished, but it's done well enough and rough enough to get it's feeling across to the player having the experience. Shrimps are also rather cute and well done, until they are turned into dinner.

Soundtrack At first, the music is slightly eerie and abrasive to create a tone, but after just a couple of minutes walking around, between the static of the TV's and the same repeated track, it began to grate on my nerves and I was quickly looking to turn my volume down, if not off completely.

Conclusion A well put together idea to have something fairly weighted and quite twisted come out in the form of a charming atmospheric story.

Honestly at the end of the day you have nothing but 10 minutes of your life to lose on giving this a go. It's something you can't simply understand and take in from watching it or reading about it. It has to be experienced first hand to really get it's point across and establish the dark tones and mood of it.

It's one of those things you come across, experience once and then never do so again because there’s no need to.

reviewText:
Listen, I don’t have long. I've got to stay ahead of this thing. The powers that be just beneath the surface of the makings of reality as we know it have sent me a signal. I burned a bowl to chill out and watch mumblecore Keanu Reeves psycho-noir thriller A Scanner Darkly, you know, like you do to test your cognitive fortitude against a super trippy movie that’s obviously trying to make someone who’s surely on drugs in the room freak the ♥♥♥♥ out, feel the hot red eye of something staring in from the outer dark. Somehow I ended up I sitting down afterward to cut the buzz with a video game, but I was intercepted by a free title called the static speaks my name. I had to tune in.

The thing says that it’s a ten minute game. And you’ll see that my play time is some 2 hours. That is because I experienced, while entrenched in this whackadoo walking simulator fattened up for an epistemological feeding frenzy, what they call on the X-Files “lost time.” First off, my high self kept hitting the Escape key to try to pause the game, which makes you have to start the whole thing over. Moreover, my girlfriend, who herself has seen her friends die at the hands of drug culture in Southern California, was understandably feeling pretty bad about the somber end to a movie featuring Robert Downey Jr. circa 2006 (e.g., A Scanner Darkly, stay with me here), and was all the more enraged that I would freely admit (albeit in a facetious manner) to being okay to continue using marijuana, which is a narcotic that bears, if we're really generous and kind of bad at abstract thought, a passing resemblance to the fictional drug at the center of A Scanner Darkly, which is itself likened to “death growing from the earth.” She stormed to the bedroom and stormed back as I ponderously poked around in the imaginary apartment of a guy living a life that he’s on the verge of departing from that very same minute (this is the part where I review the game, here). She announced that she at some point had flushed all the weed down a toilet, soon thereafter taking the stance that I obviously cared more about the drug than I could ever care for her, given that I didn’t try to stop her from storming away.

I doubted that was the case. I was just high. We made up in no time after our little screaming fit, in which I accused her of trying to script her own life, which is kind of hard and unfair thing to do around someone who’s not exactly, could we say, stomping around in the same cognitive mudpuddles as you.

As I said, we made up. She admitted that she hadn’t drowned the rest of the weed. That was a nice twist. I sat back down and took another large taste from my glasspiece, and went about settling the affairs in this video game I’d supposedly randomly found. Was its interactive experience, which can best be likened to privately performing a Hitchcockian stage play you conceived while you thought you were reduced to your most threadbare cognitive functions in a chemically-induced daydream where you discovered an ancient wisdom that to the outside observer appeared as nothing more than an impressionistic understanding of human psychology plays out in juicy, primary colors, influenced by the past hour’s experience? You bet. A Scanner Darkly? That too. But I think it was also influenced by a piece of performance art I found on Youtube a few hours prior, in which someone wearing a polyester suit designed to make their head the shape of a human’s ♥♥♥ flailed around on a stage, whooping and coughing up something that we are supposed to think is metaphorically feces.

I have tricked my brainstem into thinking I’ve seen the edge of a world that often looks very flat in the two-dimensional lives we are able to accept as comfortable, and how we are all only the vicitims of a series of accidents, that we are each the casualty of something, and that the world does not follow the scripts we intend for it. Nor does love, nor discovery, whatever else you can think of. But yet we beat on, don’t we, beating off into the burning horizon. Interactive media can change your way of life, my man.

So, just use your life to make art as best you can. That’s it. You can’t make everyone, and possibly anyone, happy, but you can damn well design a video game that can at least imagine what it would be like to change the first line of Moby-♥♥♥♥ from “Call me Ishmael” to “Hey, gang, this is George Bailey in a technicolor dream coat, and I’m here to do a little rewiring of your emotional centers with a game about the end of a life that embarked somewhere it never felt it ever belonged.”

10/10 let’s all write reviews that make the dev block our accounts

reviewText:
This game has been hailed as disturbing by the community, but after playing it myself, I don't feel that the game actually demonstrated it effectively.   It tries to, but it doesn't because it doesn't give the two most important things that all disturbing forms of entertainment need in order to work; tension and connection.

What I'm trying to say is that you already know how the game is going to end with the guy killing himself since it's spoiled right at the very first scene, not to mention the Steam page's description.  Now this could have been a foregone conclusion story which can work quite fine so long as it explored the thought process and feelings surrounding suicide.  But this game doesn't do that.

This game instead just shows you random things that you do in a mundane setting before the guy offs himself.  There was simply not an adequete amount of build-up.  There are some hints throughout the game that could have given a richer story and a look into why the guy was suicidal, such as the obsession of the same painting that was all over the house that was redone in various fashions, but the game never went into detail about them.  It was all just there, watching you and serving as background.  Therefore, I have literally no idea why the guy was suicidal and had a man in a cage that he ended up killing as well.  There's the implication that the guy in the cage was the original artist of the painting, but still, why was the main character obsessed with that painting?  What was so great about it to him?

I know almost nothing about the character except that he lives alone, has weird online chats with anonymous women, and is obsessed with that painting.  And because of that, I can't really feel attached to him.  I know that suicides are tragedies, but I don't really feel this game painted the suicide as one.  It just felt like a mundane event with how vague everything was.  I almost felt like a ghost wandering about aimlessly in this random person's last day of life, seeing and observing, but not feeling.

Despite this game being free and taking roughly 16 minutes to play, I still don't feel that this game has enough going for it to spend your time on it.  Go elsewhere if you want something that pulls at your heartstrings and unnerves you.

reviewText: Don't take the thumbs up for a good rating, because I'd really mark a midterm if it was possible.\nSpoiler alert!\nthe static speaks my name is a short gaming experience revolving around a person that's extremely obsessed (to the point of depression) about a painting and all the implications that come from it. reviewText:
*Spoilers*

While a somewhat interesting concept, the static speaks my name is a game without a message. It's essentially a walking simulator that ends in a terrible way, and the player is left to wonder if there's anything they could have done diffferently. Unfortunately there isn't, except to exit the game before the character commits suicide. The game consists of the player waking in his room, sullenly walking around noticing especially odd furnishings around the house, eating a live shrimp from a tank, making a decision on whether to release an imprisoned man, and then hanging yourself. There's no dialogue involving the thought process that brought the character here, nor is there any type of suggestion as to how the character has come to this point. The game is laden with ambiguity, which is fine if there's a message behind it, but there's nothing for the player to ponder when they complete the game. It just ends, and that's that.

I'm left to wonder if the developer set out to create a horror game, lost interest, and then slapped the suicide ending on just to complete the project.

This falls into a similar camp as 'Actual Sunlight' which I also don't recommend as it also is a game without a message. If I were to attempt to extract anything from either of the games it would that 'depression is terrible'. Obviously this is something that we can learn and understand from what we glean from those we've known who've suffered from it, or perpaps even ourselves (those who've experienced it themselves). I've yet to see a game deal with depression, its complicated nature, danger, and desperation with any kind of dignity or lesson to those on the outside of it. This game is an attempted artful representation of something that is already hard to understand and exricate yourself from, and does nothing for people who are already suffering from depression or the people who would want to play the game in order to understand depression further.

No recommendation whatsoever, there's nothing of value here.
